projectDesc.p: The Historic Images, New Technologies (HINT) project aims to enhance description and discovery of the Historical Society of Pennsylvania's graphics materials and promote the linking and sharing of content among institutions and scholars. The project will result in an update to HSP's digital image viewer and an online digital history exhibit, featuring 500 encoded political cartoons, that will demonstrate the new viewer's capabilities and provide interpretive and contextual materials to encourage users to interact with historical images in new ways. This project was funded by a grant from the National Historical Publications and Records Commission's (NHPRC) Innovation in Archives and Documentary Editing program.>

note.p: During the 1820s, the alligator became associated with the presidential campaigns of Andrew Jackson and with Jacksonian Democracy in general. During the campaigns of 1824 and 1828, Jackson and his supporters used the popular song The Hunters of Kentucky; Or, Half Horse and Half Alligator" on the campaign trail. The song, alternately titled "The Battle of New Orleans" celebrated then-General Jackson's victory at the Battle of New Orleans during the War of 1812. The reference to the "half horse, half alligator" seems obscure now, but in the early national period, this semi-mythic creature was associated with Kentuckians and the rugged inhabitants of the Southwestern territories of the early United States.

Ironically, although Jackson's candidacy was associated with the alligator symbol, Jackson's presidential rival, John Quincy Adams, actually kept a pet alligator, given to him by the Marquis de Lafayette, in a bathtub at the White House.

item.label: Britannia
item.note: Symbolic representation of Great Britain, often depicted as a woman holding a shield and a spear.

item.label: Brother Jonathan
item.note: Early personification of the United States as a man; precursor to Uncle Sam.

item.label: Columbia
item.note: Personification of America, often depicted as a woman wearing a liberty cap (or holding a staff topped with a liberty cap) and accompanied by an American bald eagle.

item.label: Death
item.note: Death is often personified as a skeleton holding a scythe. Death often wears a black cloak and hood.

item.label: Dogs
item.note: Dogs are often depicted in political cartoons as representatives of the press.

item.label: Donkey
item.note: Usage as a symbol of the Democratic Party attributed to Thomas Nast by many, but "jackass" also used in iconography of Andrew Jackson's 1828 presidential campaign. Nast also used donkey to symbolize Democratic-supporting newspaper the New York Herald during the 1870s.

item.label: Fame
item.note: Personification of fame, often depicted as a winged goddess holding a laurel wreath and a trumpet. In Greek mythology, this goddess is called Pheme; in Roman mythology, Fama.

item.label: Giraffe
item.note: In the 1870s, Thomas Nast used the giraffe to represent the New York Tribune.

item.label: Jack Downing
item.note: A fictional character popularized in a serial newspaper narrative by author Seba Smith, Jack Downing (who, over the course of his adventures, rose to the rank of Major) appears frequently in American political cartoons from the early republic as a stand-in for the American everyman.

item.label: John Bull
item.note: Symbolic representation of Great Britain, often depicted as a paunchy, middle-aged man.

item.label: Lion
item.note: Often used as a symbol of Great Britain. Nast also used lion to represent President Ulysses S. Grant

item.label: Tortoise
item.note: In political cartoons of the 1820s-1840s, the tortoise (or land-dwelling turtle) was used to symbolize the Whig party. In the circa-1829 lithographed cartoon "A New Map of the United States..." John Quincy Adams and other Whigs are shown riding on the back of a gigantic tortoise.

item.label: Uncle Sam
item.note: Representation of the United States as a man.

item.label: Unicorn
item.note: Used occasionally to symbolize Great Britain; in the 1870s, Thomas Nast also used a unicorn wearing a monocle to represent the New York Times.
